Here is the crux of the problem with your argument.  As far as I 
understand unit testing using an xUnit framework and as part of the XP 
process.  The existence of test interdependencies (outside of thread 
testing) is a code smell which is avoided.  If the xUnit framework were 
to support the concept of dependencies it would be promoting a specific 
code smell which it is intende to avoid. 

In Kent Beck's book Test Driven Development by Example one of the TDD 
patterns is called Isolated Test,  he asks the question: "How should the 
running of your tests affect one another?" and answers himself: "Not at 
all."  If you have to test a series of functions as a group which have 
to all be completed to constitute success, then do those all in one 
testFunction.

That really is it.  No dependency concept exists, because it is 
something to discourage.  Dependencies are a sign that the code needs 
more decoupling and more refactoring.

This is one of the most significant issues with my current work 
environment.  I have so much work to do to decouple each piece I work on 
from our testing database, which I have no control over.  I have to 
decouple of I want to have tests that can be run in a reasonable amount 
of time, with a minimum of coding effort and that I can be assured won't 
be broken by changes in the data in the database.

My boss keeps saying to me, why can't we just test in the database, and 
force the tests to run in a specific order.  I resist, though I can't 
convince him.

In the example, in Kent's book he relays the experience of having a test 
suite that would run overnight, and sometimes nothing would break and 
other times he'd get a printout of many pages with all of his bugs.  It 
turned out that the large printout usually meant one test failed and 
caused cascading failures through the rest of the tests due to 
dependencies.
